awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:  The Effects of Early Exposure and Language Dominance on Bilingualism
awd_abstract_narration:
This dissertation research will investigate the bilingual abilities of heritage language speakers, in order to determine the relative importance of timing and experience in bilingual language development. Both heritage (Korean) and dominant (English) language features will be examined, including the ability to process vocabulary in real-time, detect grammatical errors, and distinguish similar but different speech sounds. The primary goal is to disambiguate the contributions of early exposure (to Korean) and input dominance (of English) to early bilingual competence. A secondary goal is to identify which linguistic domains are most vulnerable to language loss/incomplete acquisition, as well as which factors contribute to the development of balanced language proficiency. 

The vocabulary experiment is designed to determine whether the asymmetric masked priming effect (L1-L2 only) observed in adult second language learners is replicated by heritage speakers. A grammaticality judgment task is employed to examine whether heritage speakers resolve the learnability problem (Pinker, 1989) in the acquisition of locative alternation and quantifier float. The speech perception experiment will test the ability to distinguish the /sta~suta/ contrast, something difficult for Koreans, as well as Korean contrasts that are difficult for English native-speakers (/s~ss/). 
	
In addition to experimental data, biographical information and proficiency test results will be collected. The collective findings should make several important intellectual and social contributions to the field. Intellectually, it will help disambiguate the effects of early experience and language dominance, both of which have often been confounded in previous studies. Socially, such data are invaluable for teachers and parents who might be struggling to understand heritage language development and who want to help immigrants with English language development and heritage language maintenance. Other social scientists, educators, parents, and policymakers will also benefit from the research findings of this dissertation as the results can inform general bilingual education in the U.S.

por.por_cntn:
We think of our “mother tongue” as if it is an essential part of who we are, which stays with us for life and shapes the way we view the world. However, our first language may not be as inalienable as we assume. The research program that Co-PI Sunyoung Lee-Ellis is conducting on heritage language speakers, which includes this project, is putting this assumption to the test, and the findings challenge the views on the implasticity of initially acquired linguistic representation.

In this project, we examined the bilingual abilities of heritage language speakers, a group whose first language (typically the language of their immigrant parents, e.g., Korean) is no longer their dominant language (e.g., English). Their unique linguistic profile provides a special window into the relative importance of the earliness and the amount of exposure that a learner receives in different languages. The linguistic abilities of Korean heritage speakers in both their heritage language (Korean) and second language (English) were examined, including their perception of speech sounds (e.g., sound discrimination), real-time processing of vocabulary words (e.g., translation priming), and grammatical intuition on structures causing a particular type of learning difficulty called the learnability problem (e.g., locative alternation). Six psycholinguistic tasks, a bilingual experience questionnaire, and Korean and English proficiency tests were administered. Data were collected from 48 Korean heritage speakers, 36 English speakers learning Korean as adults, and 36 Korean speakers learning English as adults. Heritage speakers showed the plasticity of their early-established representations, selective advantages over adult second language learners, and significant cross-linguistic interaction effects in their bilingual competence. Such findings fill critical gaps in the bilingualism literature and address three key issues – timing, input, and cross-linguistic interaction. 

Aside from the scientific findings this research contributes to the field of language acquisition, data on this population are important for global cultural/linguistic preservation. Heritage speakers are an under-served population despite their cultural and linguistic significance to society. Despite the steadily increasing scholarly interest in language loss and maintenance among immigrants, psycholinguistic research on heritage speaker’s linguistic development and ability in both their heritage and dominant languages is still meager. This is unfortunate because such information is invaluable to both social scientists and educators who wish to help this linguistic minority. An even broader impact relates to how stakeholders (e.g., immigrant parents, policy makers) strike a balance between maintenance of the heritage language and successful acquisition of English. In order to serve the immigrant family’s dual need to learn English and maintain their home language, it is necessary to understand how the two languages interact in the bilingual’s mind. Other social scientists, educators, parents, and policy makers will benefit from more research like the current project.

Modified by: Sunyoung Lee-Ellis
